 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit for  your  approval  the  report  and recommendation  on  a  proposed  policy-based 
loan and a proposed policy-based grant, both to the Kingdom of Tonga for subprogram 2 of the 
Building Macroeconomic Resilience Program.1 
 
2. 
The  program  aims  to  strengthen  Tonga’s  long-term  growth  prospects  and  capacity  to 
respond to external shocks. The programmatic approach, with three subprograms during 2016–
2018,  builds  on  previous  policy-based  operations  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and 
other  development  partners that sustain government  efforts to  improve  (i)  its fiscal  position  by 
adopting  prudent  policies  and  better  public financial  management (PFM),  and  (ii)  the  business 
climate by continuing policy, regulatory environment, and public enterprise reforms. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Development  constraints.  Tonga  faces  challenges  to  macroeconomic  resilience 
because of geographic disadvantages, exposure to shocks, and internal bottlenecks. The public 
sector  largely  drives  economic growth,  which  is  highly  volatile.  Gross  domestic  product (GDP) 
grew  1.1%  on  average  during  FY2005–FY2015,  compared  with  3.8%  globally.  Recovery  in 
agricultural  production  after  a  drought  in  2015, strong  remittances,  and construction  related  to 
Tonga’s  hosting  of  the  2019  Pacific  Games  led  to  estimated  GDP  growth  of  3.1%  in  FY2016. 
Continued construction for the Pacific Games and tourism will drive medium-term growth. 
 
4. 
Although the fiscal position has improved since the global economic crisis, Tonga remains 
dependent on external assistance. Cost overruns or funding shortfalls for the Pacific Games and 
external  shocks  such  as  substantial  crop  and  infrastructure  damage  from  Tropical  Cyclone 
Winston in February 2016 could undermine fiscal sustainability. System and capacity weaknesses 
affect procurement and financial management. Tonga’s business environment is strong relative 
to  most  Pacific  developing  countries,  but  the  private  sector  faces  several  constraints.2 Legal 
frameworks for bankruptcy, foreign investment, and contracting need further improvement, and 
the lack of reliable credit information raises the cost of extending credit to new clients. Tonga’s 
state-owned enterprises (SOEs) accounted for 19%–23% of the country’s total capital stock, but 
contributed only 7% to GDP in FY2014.3 To improve the commercial returns of the SOE portfolio, 
the government must further emphasize governance, monitoring, and divestment of assets that 
can be more efficiently operated by the private sector. 
 
5. 
Government reforms. Tonga has adopted a reform program to address constraints on 
the public and private sectors.4 Despite limited policy-making and administrative capacity and a 
political economy environment where intertwined political and social networks pose inherent risks

governments have shown persistence. The current government, in office since January 2015, is 
committed to “a more progressive Tonga supporting a higher quality of life.”5 
 
Addressing  fiscal  challenges.  The  government  is  committed  to  prudent  fiscal 
6. 
management.  Annual  average  domestic  revenue  growth  of  6.5%  outstripped  annual  average 
growth  in  recurrent  expenditure  of  5.0%  during  FY2011–FY2016.  Increased  tax  rates  on 
petroleum products and unhealthy foods (partly offset by tax reductions on healthy alternatives) 
were the major source of domestic revenue. The wage bill also went up during the period, amid 
frequent pressures for public sector pay increases and cost of living adjustments. A remuneration 
structure introduced in FY2017 is expected to stabilize longer-term wage growth, after a one-time 
cost of transitioning to the new structure. Tonga intends to minimize the cost of new developments 
and finance the Pacific Games through domestic revenues, grants, and corporate sponsorship. 
There is a moratorium on nonconcessional debt. 
 
7. 
Tonga’s fiscal situation improved as the deficit (including grants) fell from 7.4% of GDP in 
FY2011 to a modest surplus of 1.7% of GDP in FY2014. Despite strong domestic revenues, the 
fiscal  position  returned  to  a  deficit  of  3.1%  of  GDP  in  FY2016  (Table  1)  because  of  current 
expenditure  growth  (including  a  public  sector  pay  settlement) 6  and  lower  grants.  Tonga’s 
improved  debt  sustainability  led  the  World  Bank  and  ADB  to  move  from  100%  to  50%  grant 
financing. Increasing tax revenues and a declining wage bill are projected to reduce the deficit in 
FY2017–FY2018.  Excluding  grants,  the  fiscal  deficit  averaged  7.9%  during  FY2011–FY2016, 
indicating heavy dependence on external financing.

Improving the business climate. The government has introduced reforms to create a 
better business environment for the private sector and improve the efficiency of public enterprises. 
Reforms  include  a  simpler  business  registration  system,  a  new  legislative  framework  for 
receiverships,  and  a  clear  governance  framework  for  natural  resources.  Tonga  has  supported 
public–private partnerships, improved governance, and liquidated insolvent SOEs. Progressive 
implementation  of  government  initiatives  has  driven  a  general  increase  in  profitability  among

has  a  strong  performance  monitoring  framework  for  public  enterprises  and  is  the  only  Pacific 
developing  country  that  publishes  summaries  of  SOEs’  audited  annual  accounts  in  local

the performance of the public enterprise portfolio is volatile and can be further improved through 
reforms to the governance and ownership structure of individual SOEs. 
 
9. 
ADB contributions. ADB has supported government reforms through budget support and 
technical  assistance  (TA)  to  improve  Tonga’s  fiscal  performance  and  business  environment 
(figure). ADB disbursed budget support for Tonga in FY2010, FY2014, and FY2016 to address 
development  financing  needs,  cover  reform  costs,  and  provide  incentive  for  implementation 
(footnote 6). It backed the government’s tax revenue mobilization and administrative efficiency 
measures,  which  led  to  rapid  domestic  revenue  growth  (para.  6).  ADB  assists  PFM  and  civil 
service  reforms  through  TA 8 and  is  the  lead  external  partner  on  SOE  reforms.  Following  a 
decrease in the return on equity of Tonga’s public enterprise portfolio from about 5.6% in FY2006 
to  0.1%  in  FY2009,  ADB-supported  measures  to  strengthen  the  Public  Enterprises  Act  2002, 
implement skills-based SOE director selection, and commercialize selected SOEs helped push 
up the return on equity to 4.0% in FY2015. Reforms to improve SOE governance and efficiency, 
enhance  service  regulation,  and  strengthen  public  procurement  and  audit  positively  affect  and 
directly complement ADB’s sector investments.

 Impacts and Outcome 

Programmatic approach. ADB’s Building Macroeconomic Resilience Program supports 
11. 
government  reforms  through  three  subprograms  during  FY2016–FY2018.10 The  programmatic 
design  allows  for  reform  sequencing  across  multiple  areas  to  account  for  Tonga’s  limited 
implementation  capacity,  while  providing  flexibility  to  respond  to  emerging  opportunities  and 
constraints. ADB developed the policy matrix (Appendix 4) in consultation with the government 
and  other  development  partners,  and  in  alignment  with  national  priorities.  Subprogram  1  was 
completed in FY2016, and supported reforms focused on fiscal consolidation, PFM strengthening, 
and improving the business environment. 
 
12. 
Subprogram  2  continues  the  reform  agenda.  During  subprogram  1  preparation,  10 
indicative  triggers  for  subprogram  2  were  identified.  Consultation  with  the  government  on  the 
evolution  of  reform  priorities  and  context  led  to  the  finalization  of  nine  policy  actions.11 Since 
subprogram  3  will  conclude  the  program,  the  indicative  triggers  for  subprogram  3  were 
rationalized in line with government priorities and capacity, to strengthen and consolidate reforms 
implemented under subprograms 1 and 2. The overall program is expected to close in FY2018, 
prior to the general election scheduled for November 2018. ADB will discuss the need for a follow-
on multiyear budget support program with the new government after the elections. 
 
B. 
 
The  program  aligns  with  the  following  impacts  in  the  Tonga  Strategic  Development 
13. 
Framework, 2015–2025: (i) more inclusive and sustainable growth and development; (ii) a more 
inclusive, sustainable, and dynamic knowledge-based economy; and (iii) more responsive good 
governance  (footnote  5).  The  outcome  will  be  an  improved  fiscal  position  and  business 
environment  in  Tonga.  The  program  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Pacific  Approach  2016–2020 
(footnote 1), which supports greater resilience to external shocks and risks and a better business 
environment as key outcomes. 
 
C. 
 
14. 
The  program  has  four  outputs.  The  first  three  outputs  are  in  line  with  the  JPRM,  and 
continue  government  reform  efforts  supported  by  ADB  and  other  development  partners.  The 
fourth  output  responds  to  damage  from  Tropical  Cyclone  Winston  in  the  Vava’u  island  group, 
which increased financing needs in FY2016. 
 
15. 
Subprogram  2  supports  nine  policy  actions,  which  build  on  subprogram  1  reforms  and 
address the critical challenges facing Tonga in improving its fiscal position and business climate. 
The government has completed all nine actions. Additionally, nine indicative triggers have been 
identified for subprogram 3, which may be refined based on government priorities and capacity. 
 
Output  1:  Fiscal  resilience  supported.  Policy  actions  under  subprogram  1  included 
16. 
measures  to  strengthen  tax  revenue  mobilization.  The  government  conducted  a  civil  service 
remuneration review and introduced a new debt management strategy under subprogram 1. 

Outputs 

(i) 

Fiscal  targets.  Subprogram  2  supported  the  development  of  a  fiscal  strategy 
based on internally consistent medium-term targets for debt, revenue, and public 
service wage affordability. The government’s previous fiscal strategies and targets

were short term in nature. While Tonga’s fiscal management has been prudent, 
external  shocks  and  spending  pressures  related  to  the  Pacific  Games  could 
undermine sustainability. The new strategy brings together three fiscal targets to 
be maintained over the medium term: (a) external debt is below 50% of GDP, with 
only highly concessional debt contracted; (b) domestic revenue is above 22% of 
GDP; and (c) public remuneration is below 53% of domestic revenue.12 This will 
help the government’s planning, build resilience to shocks, and provide sustainable 
funding for public services. 
Tax revenues. Subprogram 2 continued tax regime changes related to health and 
the  environment  through  increases  in  selected  excise  and  import  duty  rates  (on 
fuel, alcohol, tobacco and processed food items). The government raised the fuel 
excise tax by 16% or T$0.09 per liter. It also introduced changes in other excise 
tax and import duty rates to improve revenue mobilization and provide incentives 
for the consumption of healthy foods.13 Development partners estimate that similar 
measures  under  subprogram  1  raised  excise  tax  and  import  duty  revenue 
collections by T$7.5 million (0.9% of GDP in FY2016), and that measures under 
subprogram  2  will  raise  collections  by  a  further  T$10.2  million  (1.1%  of  GDP  in 
FY2017). These reforms have contributed to raising tax revenue to an estimated 
20.7% of GDP in FY2017. 
Civil  service  reforms.  Under  subprogram  1,  the  government  conducted  a 
comprehensive public remuneration review.  Based on its recommendations, the 
government approved for subprogram 2 a new public service salary structure with 
a  revised  pay  scale  that  provides  fair  and  appropriate  remuneration  (para.  6). 
Public  servants  are  being  progressively  moved  to  the  new  payscale. 14  The 
government also introduced a moderated performance assessment process under 
subprogram 2.15 Following a brief adjustment period, these changes will achieve 
cost  savings  by  ending  automatic  salary  progressions  and  relieve  pressure  for 
universal  pay  settlements  from  civil  servants  at  the  top  of  their  pay  bands.  The 
wage bill as a share of domestic revenue is projected to fall below 50% of domestic 
revenue (in line with fiscal targets) by FY2018. 

 
17. 
Subprogram  3  will  continue  the  tax  revenue  and  civil  service  reforms  to  help  meet 
sustainable wage bill targets. ADB is presently providing TA for civil service reforms (para. 9), and 
JPRM partners expect to provide TA for the tax reforms. 
 
18.

improvements,  such  as  improved  audit  follow-up  procedures.  An  independent  regulator  with 
powers to regulate communication services was also established.16

Regulation.  Subprogram  2  supported  the  cabinet  approval  of  a  draft  national 
energy bill, which includes provisions to regulate all energy sub-sectors (electricity, 
gas,  petroleum)  under  a  combined  sector  regulator.  Regulation  of  the  energy 
sector currently involves a variety of arrangements, with the Electricity Commission 
regulating distribution and supply and the Tonga Competent Authority regulating 
petroleum prices. The bill will establish an energy sector regulator that will merge 
the responsibilities of both entities. The government will address the regulation of 
other  utilities  such  as  water  and  waste  management  after  the  energy  sector 
regulatory reform is completed. 

 
Subprogram 3 is expected to support legislation to improve labor market functioning while 
19. 
safeguarding employee rights, as well strengthening of the national energy bill. The government 
plans  to  improve  its  accounting  procedures  with  Pacific  Financial  and  Technical  Assistance 
Centre support. ADB TA will help upgrade the financial management system.17 
 
20. 
Output 3: A more dynamic and inclusive economy supported. Business environment 
reforms  under  subprogram  1  included  public  enterprise  governance  improvements  and 
commercialization of the Tonga Water Board. ADB provides advisory services through the Pacific 
Private Sector Development Initiative for these outputs.18 

Foreign investment. Foreign direct investment in Tonga is currently about 2.8% 
of GDP and is encumbered by burdensome and complex legislation. ADB’s earlier 
budget  support  saw  the  development  of  a  new  investment  policy,  which  was  a 
preliminary  step.  Under  subprogram  2,  the  cabinet  has  approved  foreign 
investment  legislation  that  makes  it  easier  to  invest  in  Tonga.  The  Foreign 
Investment (Amendment) Bill includes (a) a clearer definition of what constitutes 
foreign  investment,  (b)  new  principles  and  procedures  to  manage  reserved  and 
restricted lists, (c) transparent procedures for vetting potential investments, and (d) 
a requirement for foreign investors to report the status of their investments annually. 
Through rationalized restrictions, the bill is expected to generate increased interest 
from foreign investors, by signaling that the government is serious about cutting 
red tape and by improving the potential profitability of investing in Tonga.

23. 
Excluding  grants,  the  fiscal  deficit  in  FY2017  is  estimated  to  be  $23.8  million  (5.3%  of

domestic bonds will fill the remaining fiscal gap of $2.7 million for FY2017. Excluding grants, the 
estimated fiscal deficit is $24.4 million in FY2018 and $25.6 million in FY2019. Grants of $18.6 
million in FY2018 and $20.0 million in FY2019 will partly finance these deficits. Of these grants, 
$10.9 million is expected in the form of annual budget support (including $2.3 million from ADB). 
The rest will be filled by $5.0 million in annual budget support loans (including $2.7 million from 
ADB) and from external project financing and domestic borrowing.

A. 
 
27. 
The  reforms  will  build  Tonga’s  macroeconomic  resilience  and  ability  to  respond  to 
economic  shocks.  Envisaged  reform  impacts  include  allocative  efficiency  gains  from  the 
rebalancing of expenditure to priority areas. Increased domestic revenue from tax changes (para. 
16)  and  higher  returns  (or  less  fiscal  drain)  from  more  efficient  SOEs  (para.  20)  will  gradually 
reduce future development financing needs. A declining wage bill will also contribute to a better 
fiscal position (para. 16). Increased macroeconomic resilience will reduce the negative impact of 
external shocks, including on growth and service delivery.25

B. 
 
28. 
Promoting good governance is a key national priority. The government is implementing its 
PFM  reform  road  map,  FY2015–FY2019,  to  close  gaps  identified  through  two  PFM 
assessments. 26  Despite  capacity  limitations  stemming  largely  from  its  small  size,  the 
assessments  indicate  that,  compared  with  international  best  practice,  Tonga’s  PFM  system  is 
mostly operating at average levels. The assessments indicate that the government has the ability 
to implement its budget but there are procurement, accounting, financial reporting, and auditing 
weaknesses. This program, complemented by development partner TA (footnote 6), addresses 
those weaknesses. Tonga has taken steps to strengthen anticorruption measures, including by 
creating  the  Parliament  Standing  Committee  on  Anti-Corruption  in  2015.  Consultations  on 
appointing  an  independent  anticorruption  commissioner  are  ongoing. 27  ADB’s  Anticorruption 
Policy (1998, as amended to date) has been explained to and discussed with the government. 
ADB  will  incorporate further anticorruption-related  activities,  as feasible and  appropriate,  in TA 
support under subprogram 3. 
 
C. 
 
29. 
Extreme poverty is rare in Tonga, but material deprivation is an issue. The public sector 
is a key provider of infrastructure and services to low-income households, and output 1 will help 
ensure that the government has the fiscal resources to respond to future economic shocks and 
natural  disasters  (which  tend  to  have  an  adverse  effect  on  the  poor)  while  maintaining  critical 
public services. The government’s expenditure program includes increased allocations to social 
sectors and infrastructure. Output 2 will increase private sector competition and ensure effective 
regulation,  and make  basic goods  and  services affordable.  More  effective  electricity  regulation 
should  lead  to  lower  prices  and  improved  service  delivery,  benefiting  the  materially  deprived 
sections. Output 3 will improve the environment for private sector activity, which would help bring 
more  jobs  and  opportunities  to  Tonga.  While  subprogram  2  is  classified  as  having  no  gender 
elements,  subprogram  3  will  support  women’s  labor  market  access  and  rights,  and  women’s 
participation in the private sector through provisions under the Employment Relations Bill and the 
private sector development strategy already under preparation.28

30. 
Following  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  subprogram  2  is  classified  as 
category  C  for  the  environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples.  Program 
activities  will  be  confined  to  policy  and  institutional  reforms.  No  activity  will  result  in  or  lead  to 
involuntary resettlement, or negatively affect indigenous peoples or the environment.
